did.abstract: Correspondence, papers on types of soils and their uses, newspaper clippings, material dealing with aspects of soil erosion in the Palouse area, field diaries of Kaiser, 1936-1976, and records of his activities in soil development projects in Colombia, Nicaragua, Honduras and Iran. Includes some of his personal records. Also, maps detailing the soils, crops, and erosion of soil in eastern Washington.
did.physloc: LOCATION NOTE (MASC STAFF USE) Rolled items: Basement, rolled oversize Oversize folders: large map case

bioghist.p: Verle G. Kaiser was born in 1911. In 1922 his family traveled west from North Dakota and settled on a dairy farm near Cheney, Washington. After graduating from high school, Mr. Kaiser attended Cheney State Normal School and the Washington State College at Pullman. In 1933 he graduated with a Bachelor of Science in agriculture, and in 1934 completed an engineering degree. Before and after his engineering studies he worked for the Soil Erosion Service. Subsequently, he worked as an agronomist a district conservationist, and an area conservationist in western Washington and northern Idaho. In 1955 he became the Agronomy specialist for Washington, Idaho, and Oregon.

Kaiser was best known for his expertise in conservation problems in the Palouse. His articles have appeared in Northwest Science and in Journal of Soil and Water Conservation; he also contributed to technical bulletins of the agricultural experiment stations in the Pacific Northwest. Mr. Kaiser's work for the soil conservation service has added to the technical guides and conservation handbooks for the Palouse area. Before and after his retirement in 1972, Mr. Kaiser undertook consulting assignments for the Development and Resources Corporation in Iran, Nicaragua and Columbia. Kaiser also campaigned to have the United States Department of Agriculture adjust its programs to meet the conservation needs of the Columbia Plateau region. Kaiser died in Spokane County, Washington, in 1982.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of papers of soil scientist Verle G. Kaiser. It includes correspondence, papers on types of soils and their uses, newspaper clippings, material dealing with aspects of soil erosion in the Palouse area, field diaries of Kaiser, 1936-1976, audio recordings, and records of Kaiser's activities in soil development projects in Colombia, Nicaragua, Honduras and Iran. It also includes some of his personal records, and maps detailing the soils, crops, and erosion of soil in eastern Washington.

arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in 13 series. The arrangement roughly follows that used by Mr. Kaiser, save that folders have been alphabetized within the various series. The subject filing system used by Kaiser is somewhat informal, with separate categories and series for materials that are not mutually exclusive, so related items and subjects may be found in multiple locations within the collection.
Series 1: Agriculture. Correspondence relating to crop planting techniques and soil conservation in the Northwest.
Series 2: Agronomy. Documents concerning specific types of soils, their conservation and uses, as well as reports on Agronomy Society meetings.
Series 3: Clippings. Articles from various Northwest newspapers regarding soil and forest conservation in the region, and meetings for that purpose.
Series 4: Correspondence. Letters between Verle Kaiser and various individuals, plus letters concerning specific agricultural and conservation projects.
Series 5: Erosion. Material dealing with various aspects of soil erosion in the Palouse area.
Series 6: Field Diaries. Verle Kaiser's diaries recording his activities in the field as a soil conservation agent between 1936 and 1976.
Series 7: International Projects. Correspondence and records of Mr. Kaiser's activities in soil conservation and development projects in Columbia, Nicaragua, Honduras, and Iran.
Series 8: Personal Interests and Activities. Personal papers, including convention meetings, speeches, and slide talks.
Series 9: Pacific Northwest. Information concerning soil conservation in the Northwest, types of plants that conserve the soil, and conservation meetings.
Series 10: The Palouse. Environmental and soil conservation studies of the Palouse area ranging from 1934 to the 1970's.
Series 11: Soil Conservation. Materials providing an overview of soil conservation and of the soil conservation service in the Northwest and nationwide, from the 1930s to the 1970s.

Series 12: Maps and Graphs. Most of these items detail the soils, crops, and erosion of soils of eastern Washington. The majority are printed maps, with Kaiser's manuscript annotations and added information.
Series 13: Audio Recordings. Audiocassette recordings of presentations, speeches, and narrations of published reports.

acqinfo.p: The papers of Verle G. Kaiser were donated to the Washington State University Libraries in 1982 (MS1982-47, MS1982-54, MS 1994-36) by members of his family.

processinfo.p: The papers were arranged and described in 1985 and 1986 by Richard Illy, Harvey Young and Barbara Kovarik Gahl. The photographs of Verle G. Kaiser were removed and treated as a separate collection (PC 71). In 2010 and 2015, Series 12 (Maps and Graphs) was reprocessed by Cheryl Gunselman, and Series 13 (Audio Recordings) was added.

controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the online catalog. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons, or places should search the catalog using these headings.

controlaccess.subject: Soil conservation--Colombia
Soil conservation--Nicaragua
Soil conservation--Honduras
Soil conservation--Iran
Soil erosion -- Palouse Region (Idaho and Wash.)
